messageBody:
## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-02-28T14:11:36Z
## Message ID: 20210228-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2021-02-28T06:55Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2021-02-21T05:35Z are caused by a high speed stream starting on 2021-02-19, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 600 km/s (see notifications 20210221-AL-001, 20210221-AL-002, 20210223-AL-001, and 20210226-AL-001). The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 360 km/s. This radiation belt enhancement may also be associated with the arrival of two CMEs at L1 (2021-02-20T11:36:00-CME-001 and 2021-02-21T01:48:00-CME-001) observed on 2021-02-23 and 2021-02-24.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-02-21T05:35:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2021-02-26T12:15Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2021-02-21T05:35Z are caused by a high speed stream starting on 2021-02-19, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 600 km/s (see notifications 20210221-AL-001, 20210221-AL-002, and 20210223-AL-001). The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 415 km/s. This radiation belt enhancement may also be associated with the arrival of two CMEs at L1 (2021-02-20T11:36:00-CME-001 and 2021-02-21T01:48:00-CME-001) observed on 2021-02-23 and 2021-02-24.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-02-21T05:35:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 17, 2021 - February 23, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-02-24T22:30:09Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-02-17T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-02-23T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210224-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at relatively low levels during the reporting period. There were two C-type CMEs (see details below). Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA's Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the CME initially observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-02-20T11:36Z would impact STEREO A at 2021-02-23T09:17Z, Mars at 2021-02-25T14:42Z, and missions near Earth at 2021-02-23T00:07Z (plus minus 7 hours)(see notification 20210221-AL-003). The arrival of this CME was observed at STEREO A around 2021-02-23T10:32Z. Ongoing analysis indicates that this CME may have arrived at L1 on 2021-02-23 and will be further evaluated in the coming days.

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 4 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp = 4 occurred during the synoptic periods 2021-02-19T12:00Z-24:00Z, 2021-02-20T06:00Z-09:00Z, 2021-02-20T15:00Z to 2021-02-21T15:00Z, 2021-02-22T00:00Z-06:00Z, and 2021-02-23T00:00Z-03:00Z.  These slightly elevated values of Kp were associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-02-19. Solar wind speeds from this high speed stream reached values around 620 km/s on 2021-02-20 and decreased to around 500 km/s by the end of the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES exceeded the threshold level of 1000 pfu at 2021-02-21T05:35Z (see notifications 20210221-AL-001, 20210221-AL-002, and 20210223-AL-001) and remained elevated throughout the reporting period. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 on 2021-02-19.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the radiation belt enhancement mentioned above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-02-20T11:36Z     ~680            C               -31/-18               50                          SOHO                              

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-02-21T01:48Z     ~501            C               -20/-17               22                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 
## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-02-24T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-03-02T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at low levels for the outlook period. There are no new active regions due to rotate onto the Earth-facing disk in the next several days, as seen by STEREO-A EUVI images.  Active Region 2804 produced frequent B-class flaring during the reporting period and is expected to continue producing frequent B-class flaring during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be at low levels throughout the outlook period.  The high speed stream which began 2021-02-19 should subside early during the outlook period, but Radiation Belt Enhancement is expected to continue through the early part of the outlook period. The current disturbance in the magnetic field seen at L1 on 2021-02-24 may have been caused by the arrival of the 2021-02-21 CME following the 2021-02-20 CME.

A northward extension of the south pole coronal hole, near S25E30 at the end of the reporting period, may possibly become geoeffective near the end of the outlook period.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-02-23T13:59:10Z
## Message ID: 20210223-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remain above 1000 pfu first crossing the threshold at 2021-02-21T05:35Z; GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2021-02-22T05:50Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2021-02-19 (see notifications 20210221-AL-001 and 20210221-AL-002).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-02-21T05:35:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Mars, STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-02-21T15:08:24Z
## Message ID: 20210221-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-02-20T11:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~680 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 50 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -31/-18 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-02-20T11:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Mars and STEREO A.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Mars at 2021-02-25T14:42Z and STEREO A at 2021-02-23T09:17Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-02-23T00:07Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-6 (below minor to moderate).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2021-02-20T11:36:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210220_183300_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210220_183300_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210220_183300_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210220_183300_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210220_183300_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210220_183300_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210220_183300_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210220_183300_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210220_183300_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210220_183300_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Mars_timeline.gif


## Notes: 


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2021-02-21T05:35Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream that arrived on 2021-02-19. The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 600 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 10, 2021 - February 16, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-02-17T21:00:21Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-02-10T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-02-16T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210217-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during the reporting period. There were no significant flares.  There was one C-type CME (see details below).  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA's Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A (glancing blow) around 2021-02-19T06:00Z (plus minus 7 hours)(see notification 20210217-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 4 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp = 4 occurred during the synoptic periods 2021-02-13T09:00Z-12:00Z and 2021-02-16T03:00Z-12:00Z.  These slightly elevated values on 2021-02-13 are associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-02-13. Solar wind speeds from this high speed stream reached values around 540 km/s on 2021-02-13. The elevated Kp values on 2021-02-16 may have been associated with a weak coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-02-16.  Solar wind speeds from this high speed stream reached values of around 450 km/s on 2021-02-17.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low during the reporting period.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)
2021-02-16T15:36Z     ~885            C               -42/-29               15                          SOHO, STEREO A

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-02-17T00:00Z
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-02-23T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at low levels for the outlook period. There are some active regions as seen by STEREO-A EUVI images that may rotate to the Earth-facing disk in the next several days.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be at low levels throughout the outlook period. An extension of the south pole coronal hole roughly centered at S25E25 on 2021-02-16 of the Earth-facing disk may have resulted in high speed stream conditions being detected at STEREO-A on 2021-02-16. This coronal hole may become geoeffective towards the end of the outlook period.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (STEREO A)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-02-17T18:04:16Z
## Message ID: 20210217-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-02-16T15:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~885 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 15 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -42/-29 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-02-16T15:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A (glancing blow).  The flank of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2021-02-19T06:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2021-02-16T15:36:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20210216_191400_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif

## Notes: 

This CME event (2021-02-16T15:36:00-CME-001) is very faint in the available coronagraph imagery and the parameters listed above are based upon a preliminary analysis.

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 03, 2021 - February 09, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-02-10T20:30:54Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-02-03T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-02-09T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210210-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity was at low levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods 2021-02-07T00:00Z-06:00Z. This increase in geomagnetic activity is associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream (HSS) detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2021-02-06. Solar wind speeds reached values around 550 km/s on 2021-02-07.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES exceeded the threshold level of 1000 pfu at 2021-02-06T14:35Z (see notifications 20210206-AL-001 and 20210206-AL-002), after which flux levels remained at or slightly above background levels for the remainder of the reporting period. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt were associated with the coronal hole HSS detected at L1 on 2021-02-01. Solar wind speeds from this HSS reached values above 600 km/s on 2021-02-03.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the radiation belt enhancement described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-02-10T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-02-16T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. An unnumbered active region has recently rotated onto the Earth-facing disk as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A coronal hole structure extending from the south pole of the Earth-facing disk is visible in SDO AIA 193 and may become geoeffective near the end of the outlook period.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for January 27, 2021 - February 02, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-02-03T23:43:51Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-01-27T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-02-02T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20210203-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during the reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs. 

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 4 for the reporting period.  The highest values of Kp = 4 occurred during the synoptic periods 2021-02-02T00:00Z-09:00Z and 2021-02-02T12:00Z-15:00Z.  These slightly elevated values of Kp are associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream (HSS) detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2021-02-01. Solar wind speeds from this HSS reached values around 600 km/s on 2021-02-03.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu starting at 2021-01-27T11:45Z and stayed elevated above background levels through 2021-02-01 (see notifications 20210127-AL-001, 20210129-AL-001, and 20210131-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt were associated with the arrival of a coronal hole HSS detected at L1 on 2021-01-25. Solar wind speeds from this HSS reached values above 600 km/s on 2021-01-26.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO-A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the radiation belt enhancement described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-02-03T00:00Z
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-02-09T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be at low levels for the outlook period. Active region 12801 will rotate off the Earth-facing disk during the next few days of the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. The coronal hole HSS detected at L1 by DSCOVR/ACE on 2021-02-01 is ongoing with effects likely continuing into the outlook period. Additionally, a low latitude coronal hole is roughly centered at S20E05 of the Earth-facing disk at the start of the outlook period. This coronal hole may become geoeffective during the latter half of the outlook period.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-01-31T13:41:36Z
## Message ID: 20210131-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2021-01-31T05:45Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2021-01-27T11:45Z are caused by a high speed stream which arrived on 2021-01-25, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 620 km/s (see notifications 20210127-AL-001 and 20210129-AL-001). The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 300 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-01-27T11:45:00-RBE-001.
